This summer STAGE East and West have still been working hard - meeting to plan their next season, read plays, perform improv and work on fundraising efforts.

We would like to tell you about their summer fundraiser extraordinaire- selling STAGE facemasks- made out of recycled STAGE shirts! A team of students and parents from both campuses have spent time making non-medical grade masks both in plain black and STAGE Logo Designs. (See the logo specific design image attached).

They are pre-selling the masks NOW! See all details in the poster image attached. You can email your order to stagetix@sturgischarterschool.org and a team of STAGE students will respond and take your order. Pick up is at West on August 14th or request delivery to your home! Please pay in cash only- all proceeds go to help STAGE plan and implement a 2020-2021 season in these unprecedented times!

Thank you for your support of the STAGE program, which strives to give all students an opportunity to take risks, honor their creativity, and grow as well rounded and open minded young adults.

From May 20 to May 29, the Cape Cod Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution (Cape Cod DAR) began delivering their Good Citizens Awards. Due to the current CoVID-19 stay-at-home restrictions, the DAR’s annual formal ceremony was not possible. Instead of an in-person celebration, members of the Cape DAR Chapter created a “parade” of sorts and visited each of the homes of Good Citizens to hand deliver the awards, using social distancing and protections.

Congratulations to West Graduate Sophie Strano who was honored as a DAR Good Citizen!

On Wednesday, November 6th, more than 100 students from 10 schools gathered at the Cape and Islands Youth Climate Action Summit in Harwich. The Summit was organized by 8 High School Students, including Sturgis East students Ila Cheverie, Carly Burns and Andrew Juan. Mass State Senator Julian Cyr, Mass Congressman Bill Keating and State Representative Will Crocker addressed the students and among other things, commended them on their activism and for being a part of the summit. Students then broke out into groups where they discussed different issues around Climate Change, like Green Eating, Cape energy Consumption, political activism, careers and environmentalism, to come up with action plans for students to implement in their schools. There was a sneak peak of Crude the Musical.
Photo credits: Cape Cod Theatre Company/Harwich Junior Theatre website.

post_text: Last Friday, November 1st, STAGE held its first ever Fall Festival fundraiser! See these students and their fellow cast, crew, and pit orchestra members perform in Legally Blonde on November 22, 23, and 24 at Cape Cod Community College. Email stagetix@sturgischarterschool.org to reserve tickets and for more information.

The Environmental Systems class at East tested the air on Main Street for the presence of Tropospheric Ozone, a pollutant created when car exhaust reacts with sunlight, and air-borne particulates. They found both but, possibly because of high humidity the day of testing, levels were within a safe range. According to the American Lung Association, Barnstable County has unacceptable air quality because of the number of days per year in which the concentration of ozone exceeds safe standards. High concentrations of ozone are are associated with asthma and COPD.
For more information take a look at the article in the Boston Globe about how Massachusetts's air quality has worsened.
https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2019/04/24/massachusetts-air-quality-has-worsened-report-says/fWJ9wCaSQp60jXk6ExrNXJ/story.html

post_text: Every year, freshmen attend a day-long challenge course and team-building program at Camp Burgess & Hayward to help them learn how to cooperate, build trust, and work together effectively. At Aselton Park in the Hyannis Harbor they learn the history of William Sturgis. Just as Sturgis signed on board at sixteen for his first voyage, freshmen commit to the four-year challenge ahead by signing the Sturgis log book and ringing the ship's bell. Four years later, during the graduation ceremony, after receiving their diploma, they will sign out of the log book to signify the completion of their Sturgis voyage. Take a look at some of both campuses pics!

This summer, a group of 10 Sturgis students went to Iceland with World Challenge! Accompanied by Sturgis staff members Kyle Sevits & Natalie Sheeler, students took on a variety of challenges - from booking accommodations and travel plans, converting currency, mapping out directions for hikes, managing thousands of dollars for group purchases, buying their own groceries and cooking their own meals - to crossing freezing cold glacial streams, climbing up mountains with 50 lbs on their back, and going to sleep while the sun was still shining! Students also participated in a service activity during which they planted somewhere around 5,000 trees(!!!) in order to eliminate their carbon footprint from traveling, and contribute to the local Icelandic economy. It was truly a magnificent experience.

Students interested in attending World Challenge PERU 2020 next year should contact Mary Pawlusiak (East) or Kaitlin Doherty (West).

post_text: Sturgis Theatre Arts Guild of Entertainers (STAGE) produced their annual Winter One-Act Plays, which were performed in our new space at 529 Main Street! In preparation for these performances, STAGE held a Spaghetti Dinner Fundraiser on February 1st, which was very well attended and helped defray the costs of lighting equipment and curtains. These items, along with a stage that was generously donated and built by Sue and Bob Beardsley, grandparents of Keshet Baumflek (East STAGE student, '20), all came together to turn the warehouse into a wonderful performance space! Sturgis West performed A Simple Task by Alan Haehnel, a quirky comedy about new hire Empie who keeps trying to do a good job on her first day at work, and Sturgis East put on Say Yes!, a student-written production about Marty, who tries to rid himself of negativity by saying "yes" to every opportunity he is offered These plays will be performed again at the Massachusetts Educational Theatre Guild (METG) Preliminary Round competition at Bourne High School on March 3!

Every year, freshmen attend a day-long challenge course and team-building program at Camp Burgess & Hayward in Sandwich to help them learn how to cooperate, build trust, and work together effectively. They then travel to Aselton Park at Hyannis Harbor where they learn the history of William Sturgis.
Just as Sturgis signed on board at sixteen for his first voyage to China, freshmen commit to the four-year challenge ahead by signing the Sturgis log book and ringing the ship's bell. At the end of senior year, they'll return to Burgess to complete a ropes course and reflect on their four year journey. During the graduation ceremony at Aselton Park, after receiving their diploma, they will sign out of the log book to signify the completion of their Sturgis voyage.
Here are some pics from last week's trips, students had a blast!

Last Friday, October 6th, IB Music students from both East & West took a second trip to the Barnstable Senior Center to share a few performances and finish up their work on the ALIVE INSIDE project. In an effort to stimulate discussions and recall of musical memories, students delivered headphones with playlists tailored to the tastes of the senior citizens they interviewed last Spring. Students were excited to hear stories about some of the senior citizen's favorite musicians, learned a great deal about empathy through music appreciation, and added to their grasp of jazz and early popular music repertoire.

Alive Inside is a national Alzheimer's project that seeks to harness music’s capacity to uncover the deepest parts of our humanity by listening to and sharing music. For more information visit: http://www.aliveinside.us/#press

post_text: 47 IB Art students from East and West recently returned from a two day field trip to the Berkshires where they visited three art museums. The first stop was the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (MASS MoCA) which featured many conceptual and interactive artworks and was a favorite of the trip. The second stop was the Williams College Museum of Art, which displayed a more eclectic collection ranging from Modern to Classical works. The final museum was the The Clark Art Institute where students enjoyed the temporary exhibition of Helen Frankenthaler, whose work mesmerized them with its complexity and the time commitment required to complete it. Many thanks to all who supported this trip; students are still excited from taking in such inspirational art amidst the gorgeous backdrop of the Berkshires!

At the beginning of each school year, freshmen attend a day-long challenge course and team-building program at Camp Burgess & Hayward in Sandwich to help them learn how to cooperate, build trust, and work together effectively. Afterwards, they travel to Aselton Park at Hyannis Harbor where they learn the history of William Sturgis.

Just as Sturgis signed on board at sixteen for his first voyage to China, freshmen commit to the four-year challenge ahead by signing the Sturgis log book and ringing the ship's bell. At the end of senior year, they'll return to Burgess to complete a ropes course and reflect on their four year journey. During the graduation ceremony at Aselton Park, after receiving their diploma, they will sign out of the log book to signify the completion of their Sturgis voyage.

Check out some pics from last week's trips--despite the weather, students had a blast!
